statusbot/bot.py.message: I also manually added "use_ssl=True" to the [ircbot] section.  we shouldn't have changed the default ... but even then it wouldn't connect.
Oops, use_ssl should have been set to True in the else case.
Is this maybe supposed to be Bot(SSL, base) ?

Arg, unfortunately, using `class Bot(SSL, base)` results in

 Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "statusbot/bot.py", line 612, in <module>
    main()
  File "statusbot/bot.py", line 597, in main
    _main(args.config)
  File "statusbot/bot.py", line 576, in _main
    Bot(channels, nicks, publishers, successlog,
  File "/lib/python3.8/site-packages/ib3/connection.py", line 32, in __init__
    super(SSL, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs)
 TypeError: __init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'connect_factory'

I think that that is pretty likely the issue, because the SSL mixin does some patching in its init() before calling super(), which comes late when the base class is referenced before.
Note that even switching this would still make the resulting class (SSL, SASL, base) instead of (SASL, SSL, base) which we had before, but SASL is calling super() first, so that hopefully shouldn't matter as much.
It seems like this is happening because SASLStatusBot or NoSASLStatusBot defines a __init__ function. Though I'm not sure what can be done to support non-ssl server.

INSERT INTO kube_cmd_versions VALUES (NULL, '2021-10-14 02:27:17.126427', NULL, 1, '1.21.3', '1.21.3');
could this be performed via the 'command' module ?  My understanding is that 'command' is preferred over 'shell'

can use command module, let me make that change.

Originally I was using shell for a few reasons:
- I was doing multiple commands with pipeline
- I had complex command that had to embed single and double quotes, and the formatting was easier to see with YAML formatting with literal block string, BUT, I still was having trouble with escaping and quoting.

Just an example to show what I mean,
- name: test task
  shell:
      cmd: |
          cut -f 1 -d: /etc/passwd | xargs -n 1 -I {} bash -c ' echo -e "\n{}" ; chage -l {}'

I removed all of that in favour of the native regex_search(), so the shell should no longer be required.

lib/keystone.message: IMO it is a bit confusing that this user has both admin and member roles, is this needed? Would it be possible to drop this? Or do the same thing as with the demo project and have this user be member only and add a new alt_demo_admin user instead of _member?

Yeah - I'm not sure if it's needed or not... all this stuff has been around for a long time so I'm not sure I understand the reasoning behind why certain users have a role or not.

FWIW - my goal was to have multiple personas available for people to experiment with. For example, having reader, member, and admin applied to the system and at least two projects. I thought this would help people get familiar with the various personas and how they work, without having to do the same setup each time they deploy devstack.

Adding the 'admin' role to this user on the alt_demo project ensures the alt_demo project has an admin of some kind (e.g., possibly useful for testing tenancy across projects).

/COMMIT_MSG.message: And it isn't possible for addChange to be executed again because a single scheduler at a time is processing events for a pipeline. And when the event is pulled off we never put it back again to be processed by another scheduler in the vent of a failure? Basically we either process it here and we're good or we don't and move on?

Exactly; the trigger event queue is a try/finally:
https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul/src/branch/master/zuul/scheduler.py#L1872

It may be possible to have some ZK error that causes us to report enqueued and then fail to remove the event; however, we try almost indefinitely to write the pipeline state to ZK before we leave queue processing, so that is unlikely.

Hi Oleg. This is what I was suggesting: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/815095

Same as with QoS binding objects, here "LocalIPAssociation" registers will link "LocalIP" with "Ports". But "LocalIP" object should not refer to them in its view model (that means no adding "port_associations" member). This is because "LocalIPAssociation" is not a child object from "LocalIP"

"LocalIPAssociation" should not refer neither to "LocalIP" in its view model (OVO model). Please check I also removed "id" from "LocalIPAssociation".

In order to have in "LocalIP" a reference to a list of ports (or port IDs), you can add "port_associations" but as a list of strings. During the OVO load, you can populate manually the Port list or just the port IDs (the second one will be much faster).

Next patches in relation chain may better show my intent: user associates some port with Local IP (created earlier) - LocalIPAssociation object is created - push notification is issued - agent gets LocalIPAssociation and can get needed LocalIP info from it (local ip address, ip_mode), along with fixed port id and fixed ip address.

Hi Rodolfo, thanks for such a thorough review and research! I left comments inline 

> Hi Oleg. This is what I was suggesting: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/815095
> 
> Same as with QoS binding objects, here "LocalIPAssociation" registers will link "LocalIP" with "Ports". But "LocalIP" object should not refer to them in its view model (that means no adding "port_associations" member). This is because "LocalIPAssociation" is not a child object from "LocalIP"

But actually "LocalIPAssociation" is a child of "LocalIP".

> 
> "LocalIPAssociation" should not refer neither to "LocalIP" in its view model (OVO model). Please check I also removed "id" from "LocalIPAssociation".

But this is exactly what I need: having LocalIPAssociation object I want a quick access to parent LocalIP to get actual local IP address and other parent attributes. Thus new LocalIPAssociation objects will be communicated to OVS agent via push notification mechanism. Then agent will have all needed info in one object update.

> 
> In order to have in "LocalIP" a reference to a list of ports (or port IDs), you can add "port_associations" but as a list of strings. During the OVO load, you can populate manually the Port list or just the port IDs (the second one will be much faster).

In fact I don't need a list of associated ports. LocalIPAssociation updates are central in server - agent communication.

Ok, I will not continue this discussion. According to [1], foreign_keys was to be used in a child object to create a reference to the parent object and, in the parent object, populate the child objects content. In [2] or this patch, this is not happening.

I'm ok if this patch is merged.

[1]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/1ad9ca56b07ffdc9f7e0bc6a62af61961b9128eb/doc/source/contributor/internals/objects_usage.rst
[2]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/objects/network.py#L109

> "LocalIPAssociation" is not a child but a binding record. It is used to link ports with LocalIPs.

Yeah, agree, I meant from an API perspective.

> 
> There are many binding register types in Neutron that are not used in the linked OVO views. For example:
> FlavorServiceProfileBinding
> DvrFipGatewayPortAgentBinding
> L3HARouterAgentPortBinding
> SecurityGroupPortBinding
> NetworkDhcpAgentBinding
> PortSecurityBinding

> 2) (The one I would use) Same as, for example, QoS bindings: create a syntethic field in LocalIP and populate the fixed_port_ids and fixed_port_ips values (I think you just need those two) when calling LocalIP.modify_fields_from_db, doing a query

I think LocalIPAssociation binding is a bit new/unique here as its create/delete events are central (even only) part in server-agent communication - this is simple and straightforward IMO (better than handling LocalIP updates and iterate port_associations to get the diff). That's why I'd like to have the reference to LocalIP object in LocalIPAssociation, not the other way around. 
OVO must have a native way to do this, to not go to a lower level db_obj relationship. The only native way I found is via foreign key in LocalIP - according to code this seems required. Also this is already used in [1]
If there is a more proper way for using synthetic object fields to reference binding "parents" - I'm happy to use it :)

[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/objects/network.py#L109

"LocalIPAssociation" is not a child but a binding record. It is used to link ports with LocalIPs.

There are many binding register types in Neutron that are not used in the linked OVO views. For example:
FlavorServiceProfileBinding
DvrFipGatewayPortAgentBinding
L3HARouterAgentPortBinding
SecurityGroupPortBinding
NetworkDhcpAgentBinding
PortSecurityBinding
NetworkSecurityBinding
QosNetworkPolicyBinding
QosFIPPolicyBinding
QosRouterGatewayIPPolicyBinding
QosPortPolicyBinding

If you still want this, I recommend you two alternatives:
1) Use the orm relationship, like in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/815095/5/neutron/db/models/local_ip.py (check PS5)
2) (The one I would use) Same as, for example, QoS bindings: create a syntethic field in LocalIP and populate the fixed_port_ids and fixed_port_ips values (I think you just need those two) when calling LocalIP.modify_fields_from_db, doing a query
I tested that API locally and it seems it's working fine.

There are some code in agent side should be move to this commit. And the entire implementation order should be:
1. neutron-server side (API/DB/plugin) works with some resource notification changes
2. "Add Local IP L2 extension flows" which only added helper functions on br-int
3. "Add Local IP L2 extension" which add the whole extension, the new extension will use the flow functions on br-int
4. policy works
5. test works
...

So you implement the agent extension in two patches, same as the DB/plugin related changes. This is a merging question, there is no standard answer. But for integrality, we should not leave some tails to other commit.

I have another approach is to merge that "flows" and "agent extension" into one commit. Neutron has some feature implemented like that, so it will be two patches, one is neutron-server side and another is in agent side. Then this will be:
1) API/DB patch only has code needed for API/DB to work
2) Agent extension patch with flow works.
This is also following your principle: add the flows code that is needed by agent extension.
May I wonder if there's something that blocks this DB patch? We can continue discussion about extension in related patches :)

Hi Yulong. In implementation I tend to stick to the following principle: only add code that is needed in current patch. This makes review easier IMO - you don't need to open other patches to figure out how this code will be used. Thus I'd prefer to stay with current order: 

 1) API/DB patch only has code needed for API/DB to work
 2) Agent extension patch adds mechanism for server <-> agent communication on Local IPs
 3) Agent flows patch: fills agent extension with actual flows logic.

Please share your opinion, what are major drawbacks with this approach? Is it a blocking issue?
Looking forward to the higher level tests

pkg/container/api.go.message: Why is it necessary to pass timeout as input parameter for this method? You can get this value from env right here (inside of Run), and in this case you would do it just once (instead of many times when calling Run from other places). Also, if particular container doesn't support timeout, this change will force developers to specify dummy timeout value (like 0) in order to call this method.

We have explanation in the original issue on github. On the design call we discussed two approach - the first one change container API, the second one get parameters from env variable. You can find detailed description on the github issue - https://github.com/airshipit/airshipctl/issues/544

I see, however it's not clear for me why we need to change API and pass optional parameter which can be retrieved the same way inside of Run function, also it will introduce additional complexity for calling Run() method since specifying timeout becomes mandatory in this case. From my perspective, timeout should be optional because not every container actually needs the timeout and we should have no-wait option (like in case of k8s-apply executor). Also, timeout can't be negative, so it's better to use unsigned int instead for this variable.
Am I right, that you just check if timeout == 0? time.Duration is int64 under the hood, so you can use timeout == 0 directly
why not just `ctx, cancel := context....` without declaring the variable cancel

validation container doesn't support timeout and it would be redundant to define one for it, since you never know number of input documents to validate and how many kinds you have to process, and depending on that time needed for validation can significantly vary. also validation container basically has no operations which can stuck and validation process is not a part of deployment pipeline. why did you try to define timeout here?
I added it here because I changed API and I need to pass value to Run() method. I think that validation container can ignore the timeout.

pkg/phase/executors/container.go.message:
I'm not sure that this is a proper way to get timeout value. Why didn't you introduce timeout field for Generic Container executor like it was done for Kubernetes Apply? And also such env variable eliminates the possibility to define different timeouts for containers (or you have to set a new value for env variable before running each phase - which is not possible in case of plan execution scenario). I believe timeout should be defined within manifests rather than via env. If you want to stick with env - you can just simply pass its value inside of container without any processing in airshipctl.

Another point against - this approach ignores timeout value which could be set via CLI options of phase run command.

pkg/util/env.go.message: much easier to allow user to set the timeout value in time.Duration notation (10s, 30m, 1h, etc) and then parse it using time.ParseDuration()

It was just a suggestion, up to you how to implement it. From my perspective, it's easier for both (developers and end users) to use notation which is more flexible and closer to human interpretation of time (seconds, minutes, hours) without conversion to seconds, and then double conversion in source code from string to int and then to string again.
I agree it will be easier from the developer side, but from the user side this will add ambiguity. Because of this I specified the unit of timeout in the env variable - `TIMEOUT_SECONDS`

Hey Andy, I guess I was looking at this: https://opendev.org/starlingx/upstream/src/commit/a4046414b634e027f646be58502f3af2ea2329f0/openstack/python-keystone/centos/files/password-rules.conf#L17  But I do see on a running system the keystone.conf specifies minimum value of 0 as you noted.  Do we want the user to be able to set 0 then (disable)?

The default value is actually 0 (disabled the feature). From the keystone.conf:

# This controls the number of previous user password iterations to keep in
# history, in order to enforce that newly created passwords are unique. The
# total number which includes the new password should not be greater or equal
# to this value. Setting the value to zero (the default) disables this feature.
# Thus, to enable this feature, values must be greater than 0. This feature
# depends on the `sql` backend for the `[identity] driver`. (integer value)
# Minimum value: 0

Think about it again ... we currently set it to 3, meaning user can reuse the last 2 passwords in history. Setting it to 1 would mean user doesn't have restriction on the new password, seems to be the same result as setting to 0. One different between 0 and 1 maybe, 0 totally disables the checking (the feature). Since keystone supports 0, I still think it's better for service parameter to support 0.
I would think we should support setting it to 0 (disable), so we are aligned with what keystone supports.
I changed the code to accept zero values, so it reflects what is in keystone documentation.

The puppet change would also need to part of stx.5.0 so that it would support formatting the ceph monitor addresses correctly on controller-1 unlock. As this is the first node upgraded in a multi node setup, it will need to have the correct addressing to talk to the Mimic v1 monitors.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/conductor/ma.message:
Use existing patterns:

 ceph_storage_backend = StorageBackendConfig.get_backend(
            self.dbapi,
            constants.SB_TYPE_CEPH)

Add:
  LOG.info("Ceph Upgrade: Checking monitor states")

Add:
  LOG.info("Ceph Upgrade: Monitor %s is not upgraded to %s" % (mon.hostname, upgrade.to_release))

Add: 
  LOG.info("Ceph Upgrade: Monitor %s has not applied the latest configuration changes" % mon.hostname)

Add:
  LOG.info("Ceph Upgrade: Enabling monitor msgr2")

This is probably OK for now, but for a future update may want to consider:

- Add a timeout to this call to timebox how long we'll allow this to run, this should be a quick operation if all iw working correctly
- Add a defensive try/exception around this in case the REST API is not accessible or there is a problem so that we log a message and try again on the next audit cycle
- If we have a break in the quorum or ceph mgr is not running for some reason, will this API call take a long time to time out and block the audit? If so we could offload this logic to the HandleUpgradesMixin in utilities/ceph/ceph-manager/ceph-manager/ceph_manager/monitor.py
Will address this in a future commit and create a task in SB for this.

I prefer your workaround (reboot the VM) instead of recreating it. The reason are following:
 - rebooting is faster than recreating the stack
 - in case of multiple compute nodes we could end up of hitting the same bug on another hypervisor host with the new server while rebooting never changes the hypervisor host.
An assert method should raise a failure exception. Anyway I don't thing we do need this.
I changed name of the method. I don't want to raise exception here as it just needs to try to reboot server if ssh is not available and move on. Exception is not necessary.

This is not going to work. This function requires SSH connectivity to work therefore it cannot be use to workaround DHCP issues. I would just use the same implementation as we used for CirrOs Image. The only thing I would do here is setting a different matching pattern for every distribution and eventually make it configurable. For example we could catch some well known cloid-init message.
ok, it now can be set "per class"

We should capture the InvalidStackError at this line and then trigger the workaround. On the contrary we will ALWAYS re-create the server (or fail after N retries) instead of running the workaround.
Ok. Let's skip all other verifications if server didn't boot properly.

I think if the server boots until the end then we should assume no workaround is needed and that SSH it is going to work (when we are going to need it). If it is not booted before the timeout then we reboot-it and expect it will get the correct IP from the DHCP after the reboot.
No, server will boot even without metadata available. The problem is that in such case ssh key will not be configured thus ssh will not be possible.

I think this verification is redundant. If login has been printed then we should assume SSH works. If it is not printed then we reboot the VM and expect it is going to work. In any case there is any need to wait for SSH to get ready for the purpose of the workaround implementation.

No, "login:" will be printed even with metadata service will not work properly. But in such case ssh-key will not be configured thus ssh will not work and in such case reboot is needed to workaround that potential bug.

Done
OK. I follow now. Please update the commit log to include something like what you say here so it is clear to anyone reading the commit in the future.

Exactly, we only has one base-bullseye.yaml, which is used to customize the final OS. No such a yaml for initramfs. LAT uses a default configuration to generate the initramfs, as a result, the kernel is hard code to linux-image-amd64 of debian bullseye. That causes we can't switch the kernel to yocto in final rootfs. This is the first step of transition Yocto kernel. Also need to update build-image script, and update base-bullseye.yaml, etc.

After talking to Lance we decided to use the "admin" role for this system-specific API.
Get rid of this custom role.
Just to clarify here, we're removing these because we're not overriding them, so we're just letting the defaults in code come though.
Right.  In code, all of these base rules will still be defined.  However, they won't be used because they're not used in the policies that we are overriding.

Does this also need to check for tenancy? What would happen if someone in project foo created a secret with read_project_access True and I used a token scoped to project bar to access that secret?

It looks like this check just ensures the read_project_access attribute is True, but it doesn't ensure I'm actually a member of the project.

This check is a base rule and it's meant to be used with other rules that check tenancy.  e.g.

    rule:secret_project_member and rule:secret_is_not_private_read

This rule is not used by itself.

Similar comment as below.

nit:

Does is_not_private only mean that the container is supposed to be viewable to other people in the project? Not other people in the deployment, right? Because by default containers/secrets are filtered based on users who created them I think?

If so, I wonder if something like:

  barbican-container-project-visible:
    key: "container_project_visible"
    value: "..."

would make that more clear?

I chose to use the negative definition for this specific rule (not_private vs visible) becuase it makes the compounded rules a little easier to read.  e.g.  I think this:

    "rule:container_project_member and (rule:container_owner or rule:container_is_not_private_read) or rule:container_acl_read or rule:container_project_admin"

is easier to read than:

    "rule:container_project_member and (rule:container_owner or not rule:container_project_visible) or rule:container_acl_read or rule:container_project_admin"

I'm not opposed to changing it if you think the second way is better in a complex rule like that.  (I was also unsure if you can use "not" in a policy rule)

This means someone with the admin role on a project will pass this check, which is probably fine given the rest of this environment file assumes project-admin's are operators of the deployment.

But, it will mean that operators need to have a token scoped to the secret's project they want to manage, as opposed to just having an token with the admin role scoped to any project, correct?
Yes, that's correct.  The operator's token will have to be scoped to the project that owns the secret, not just any project.

>>> a=1

TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for +: 'int' and 'str'

you probably need to do str(self.chassisid) + str(self.portid) + str(self.portname)

str(self.portname) is to handle a case where portname is None

lt and gt are using str  but le and ge are not.

Try using __hash__ which you updated above.  it guarantees you always are using the same value for all comparisons

ex:
return self.__hash__() <= rhs.__hash__()

What is the specific use-case for these four functions, and what exactly does "less than" mean when we're talking about a tuple of chassis ID, port ID, and port name?

The hash is really a unique identifier that only makes sense to test for equality.  Changing one part of it slightly can result in huge changes in the output.  As an example:

>>> hash((1, 2, "blah"))
-4649835305422604239
>>> hash((1, 3, "foo"))
7070402611994814150
If we don't ever need to sort these, why are we implementing these functions at all?

We need to provide the rich comparison methods for ordering in Python 3, which are __lt__, __gt__, __le__, __ge__, __eq__, and __ne__.

On Python 3 
__cmp__ is no longer used.

I don't know enough of this repo business to provide a good lt, gt comparison.
Could you help me with that?

The original __cmp__ method was just doing that:
    def __cmp__(self, rhs):
        return ((self.chassisid < rhs.chassisid) or
                (self.portid < rhs.portid) or
                (self.portname < rhs.portname))

I tried to follow the same logic on that plus the review comments that you guys made.
Looking further down in this file, the __eq__() and __ne__() functions in the Agent class are logically inconsistent, because you could have a situation where both functions evaluate to True.
I think it's ok to remove in this changeset.
Because if we're doing it just because it might be used somewhere, then I question whether the hash() implementation is sufficient since it's essentially a random (but consistent) order.

Chris,  those values are typically only ever used when some kind of 'sort' method is called on a python list.   As long as they are consistent, it doesnt matter.
Often times, there is an integer value (like a subcloud ID) or a string (subcloud name),  but for this object it looks like the original author wanted 3 fields.
I dont think we ever sort these anywhere.

We don't need to do any sorting on the key, so I think the cmp, le, gt, lt, ge can be removed.  Chris is right about the Agent and Neighbour class below.  We should clean this up, but it's probably out the scope of this changeset.

The CinderPureIscsiCidr parameter needs to be defined, above.

I think this is a situation where something like "none" would work instead of '' (empty string). The conditional at L126 will ensure the hiera variable is set only when there's an actual host personality to configure.

I know your puppet-cinder patch uses the magic "$::os_service_default" method of specify the default value, and that's important because openstack puppet is used by multiple deployment tools and therefore needs to be non-opinionated. But it's OK for tripleo to be more opinionated, and here it means you could set the default value to "0.0.0.0/0" (which, I know, is the driver's default value).

I mention this because '' doesn't inform the user what they'll get unless they override the default value.

An alternative might be to enhance the description to tell the user that a blank string is equivalent to "0.0.0.0/0" (any valid IPv4 host).

Hmm, that raises another question. If the Pure Storage backend supports IPv6, then how would that affect things?

IPv6 support for the iSCSI CIDR only became available and is supported by the _list param we will be adding in a subsequent patch.
This patch will be backported to Wallaby which doesn't support the _list parameter nor IPv6

Sorry, I should have been more clear. The 'None' on L83 would need to be in the list of allowed_values (or 'none' to be consistent about using lower case). THT doesn't interpret None in the same manner that python does. Here, 'none' is simply a string.

And, to be doubly sorry, I'm rethinking my suggestion to use 'None' (or 'none'), and maybe a blank value is easier to understand. If you could enhance the description the same way you did for the CinderPureIscsiCidr parameter (L94..95) and change L83 back to '' then it will lgtm. That way both parameters follow the same convention of using a blank string.
This should probably be 'none' (not a blank string) per my previous comment.
Nevermind, I'm now thinking '' is the better approach.

didn't get your question. the flow is the following:
 1. if provided a file_path with --config-file-path, we will use it during all the processing, and fail at some point if the file path is invalid (os.path validations)
 2. if file_path was not provided, but we are downloading from a url, we will try to use the same name, if it ends with '.repo'
 3. if those above fails, out file_path will be none and the code will search in the config_dir for repo files that have the same repo name (e.g delorean-component-baremetal) and update it.

at the end, if the users want to guarantee that an specific repo file exists and will be updated with that info, they can always provider the correct file_path.

The line that we check if a file_path was provided or we will search for config files in the repos dir: https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-repos/blob/da713cb3593018485e5d784e2b5523c416ab3845/plugins/module_utils/tripleo_repos/yum_config/yum_config.py#L234

releasenotes/notes/deprecate-floppy-driv.message: This doesn't talk about the upgrade implications for users on this device type. What are they expected to do?

That's not what this means. This image metadata property allows you to set the bus used for all floppy disk-type devices, similar to how 'hw_disk_bus' allows you to set the bus used for a hard disk-type devices. It would be better to state this as an addendum, i.e.

  The ``hw_floppy_bus=fd``, used to configure the bus for floppy disk-type
  devices, is similarly deprecated.
Sloppy wording on my part; yes, that makes sense.

There's more than this. Users can specify that block devices be attached as a floppy disk-type device when creating their instance using the 'device_type' key of the BDM v2 body. For example:

  openstack server create \
    --block-device uuid=foo,source_type=image,disk_type=floppy,disk_bus=fd \
    ...

This resolves to the following field in the object sent to the API, fwiw:

  {
    ...,
    'block_device_mapping_v2': {
      'uuid': 'foo',
      'source_type': 'image',
      'disk_type': 'floppy',
      'disk_bus': 'fd'
    },
    ...
  }

So we also want to deprecate the ability to create block devices using this device type.

You can't just remove it. Policy doesn't allow this [1], and it's also an awful UX for the potential user that is using this. This needs a bit of thought, unfortunately.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/tags/assert_follows-standard-deprecation.html

Ah, yes.

Although, I highly doubt there are any — if at all — deployments with these kind of floppy block devices.  So I'm tempted to just nuke it.  When I brought up this on the list two years ago, nobody said a word (except that "fine to nuke it").  So I have to wonder if this special-coding to deprecate is worth the effort.
Lets suggest a replacement for disk_type=floppy

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I think we can come up with something a little more descriptive of the actual issue here.

Avoid race between attachment and volume deletion requests?
Definitely sounds a lot better.
As I've said elsewhere this behaviour is wrong and needs to be addressed in cinder-csi, they need to poll n-api os-volume_attachments to determine when a volume is detached, not the state in cinder.

https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=detach-a-volume-from-an-instance-detail#detach-a-volume-from-an-instance

"This is an asynchronous API, callers should poll the list of volume attachments provided by GET /servers/{server_id}/os-volume_attachments to determine when the detachment of the volume has completed successfully."

FWIW I added the above to the api-ref a while ago for Nova.

I disagree, Nova and Cinder should be robust enough to support getting reasonable requests.  In this case requesting the deletion of a volume in "available" state is 100% reasonable.

In this case this is a bug in Cinder, because we are setting a final state on the volume service before we have actually finished the operation and then try to set it again on the api service, which is wrong and inconsistent with our other operations.
nit - bug
thanks  :-)

I've gone over the cinder-csi code and AFAICT the trigger isn't the state but the instance being listed as in attachments [1][2] of the volume.

I've raised the following issue in cinder-csi for this:

https://github.com/kubernetes/cloud-provider-openstack/issues/1645

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/v3/index.html?expanded=show-a-volume-s-details-detail#show-a-volume-s-details
[2] https://github.com/kubernetes/cloud-provider-openstack/blob/61f2129345c6ab854ec464bc85e0b558f011b08e/pkg/csi/cinder/openstack/openstack_volumes.go#L370-L381

With the current code the status becomes available automatically upon deletion of the last attachment, so these 2 are synonymous when doing a detach.

In any case, it's definitely a good idea to make it explicit in the commit message that the check from CSI is on the attachments.
This is a bug in cinder-csi
I don't agree, if a volume is available (which is when we have 0 attachments) we should be able to safely delete it.
Locking by volume UUID would at least allow R1 to finish before it started on R2 here.
This would force the usage of a DLM to fix the issue, which is not ideal, since A/P deployments don't have it.
I don't mind covering this corner case in Nova tbh but ultimately this entire usecase is still borked IMHO.

What I'm focusing here is the fact that it should be possible to delete a volume in available state, regardless of what operation is ongoing with Nova.

I don't know if it's worth doing that in Nova, this is 100% a bug in Cinder, and a potential improvement in Cinder-CSI.
There are cases where requests to delete an attachment made by Nova can race other third-party requests to delete the overall volume.
Done
where it first requests that Nova detach a volume before itself requesting that the overall volume is deleted once it becomes `available`.
Done

I know we disagree on this but could you reference this somewhere?

https://github.com/kubernetes/cloud-provider-openstack/issues/1645

I have added a reference at the end of the commit message.

To clarify, I disagree that the solution to this issue is in Cinder-CSI, because I think Cinder should get it fixed; but I think you are right in Nova being the source of truth regarding its attachments.

FWIW I'm following up on the Nova side as I said I would with the following series:

https://review.opendev.org/q/topic:%2522bug/1937084%2522+project:openstack/nova
Thanks!  I've added it to the commit message as well.

Setting the relation data from a single unit feels wrong. If for some reason that unit is removed the application at the other end of the relation no longer sees any of the relation data. Obviously you could just remove the break but thats going to cause a large escalation in the number of hooks executions on the other side of the relation. This feels like a very good match for using the application relation data bag rather than the unit data bag. If the charm is running on an old version of juju the charm could catch the resulting exception and revert to the old behaviour. Obviously this would require a change on the other end of the relation to read the keydata from the application data bag if its there and fallback to the unit data bag if it isn't.

I think we are on the same page with regards on how the relation stuff works, although I did learn about the relation_set --app, which currently none of the charm appear to use (I grepped for app=True across all charms). Regarding the "break", I think you misread the loop. The code is already running on the nova-cloud-controller charm, and it would iterate on remote units (nova-compute), therefore it would stop iterating after the first remote unit, so it would be able to write to its "one" so "many" can read. I tested with 3 ncc units and all of them run the hook because there is no is_leader() check, so all of them write to their bag so all remote units can read. Tests I've done:

before running the upgrade (upstream code):
juju run -u nova-cloud-controller/0 'relation-get -r cloud-compute:15 authorized_keys_max_index nova-cloud-controller/0'
3
juju run -u nova-cloud-controller/1 'relation-get -r cloud-compute:15 authorized_keys_max_index nova-cloud-controller/1'
3
juju run -u nova-cloud-controller/2 'relation-get -r cloud-compute:15 authorized_keys_max_index nova-cloud-controller/2'
3
juju run -u nova-compute/0 'relation-get -r cloud-compute:15 authorized_keys_max_index nova-cloud-controller/2'
3
juju run -u nova-compute/1 'relation-get -r cloud-compute:15 authorized_keys_max_index nova-cloud-controller/1'
3

after the upgrade (with break statement):
juju run -u nova-cloud-controller/0 'relation-get -r cloud-compute:15 authorized_keys_max_index nova-cloud-controller/0'
6
juju run -u nova-cloud-controller/1 'relation-get -r cloud-compute:15 authorized_keys_max_index nova-cloud-controller/1'
6
juju run -u nova-cloud-controller/2 'relation-get -r cloud-compute:15 authorized_keys_max_index nova-cloud-controller/2'
6
juju run -u nova-compute/0 'relation-get -r cloud-compute:15 authorized_keys_max_index nova-cloud-controller/2'
6
juju run -u nova-compute/1 'relation-get -r cloud-compute:15 authorized_keys_max_index nova-cloud-controller/1'
6

ok, I see, that makes sense. You were right the break is not leading to the edge-case I was worried about. I'm happy to land this as is or do you want to reinstate the break. Thank you for taking the time to work through it with me.

Liam, I have reviewed the code w.r.t your concern, but I am unable to see how it is impacted.

First, let me try to summarize the workflow of the 2 ways the relation can be set for this:

1) upgrade-hook: it will iterate across all units and all relations updating their ssh-key (L1201). Then it needs to broadcast the update to all remote units. The relation data is set at L988 for a given cloud-compute relation-ID. By writing once, it will trigger a relation-changed hook in all compute-nodes in that relation. At L988 I don't see it setting the data for a specific remote unit, therefore since all nova-computes are affected when writing once to the relation, there doesn't seem to be a need to continue to iterate and write the same data multiple times since there is no remote unit context for this. That's why the break is there. The loop exists because it is necessary to read a remote setting from that cloud-compute relation in from any compute (all of the computes in that relation-ID will be configured the same).

2) relation-changed: previous to change, a relation-changed-hook would trigger a ssh key update and at L988 write solely to the relation that unit that triggered the relation-changed hook belongs to. However, now we need to broadcast the updated ssh key to all of the relation-IDs, not just the one pertaining to the unit that triggered the hook. Therefore we will need to iterage, very similarly to the upgrade-hook path. Again at L988 the remote context is not relevant because we are writing to a relation-ID.


From your statement:

"Setting the relation data from a single unit feels wrong.": I am confused about what this means. *From* a single unit, do you mean only from a nova-cloud-compute unit? There is no is_leader() check. If meant *For* a single unit, as the remote nova-compute unit, I covered it above, but I'm intrigued as to why it would be a problem.

"If for some reason that unit is removed the application at the other end of the relation no longer sees any of the relation data": interpreting you're talking about the nova-cloud-controller writing to the relation, then again, there is no is_leader() check, so all ncc units will have the data written to the relation. If it is the remote nova-compute you're referring to, then it is also not a problem because all units read what the ncc unit has written to the relation, it does not rely on a single compute unit existance for the data to be available.

"Obviously you could just remove the break but thats going to cause a large escalation in the number of hooks executions on the other side of the relation": If that would solve the problem then I'm even more confused as to what relation data or corner case we are talking about. Maybe I'm failing to understand that corner case. Either way, I can remove the break, and in fact, it does not cause any increase in hook executions (I retested this) because as Alex and I found out recently, the relation_set calls are all aggregated to be run once at the end of the hook. So instead of running for each unit for each relation-id, it will run just once for each relation-id at the end of the hook because it is just being aggregated with the same data. Removing the breaks will just cause the ncc hooks to take longer as it iterates further redundantly. The relation-changed hook will be triggered just once (3 if we have 3 ncc units, which triggers the hook redundantly, but maintains consistent relation-data across all nccs) on each nova-compute unit. This relation-set aggregation behavior is present since juju 2.3.0. I had the breaks added when I first thought the multiple relation_set calls would have a performance impact, and I forgot to remove them once Alex and I found out that they wouldn't have any impact.

"This feels like a very good match for using the application relation data bag rather than the unit data bag": By looking at the docs I see those bags and buckets but could only make sense of that design for the operator framework. This is a classic framework charm so I only see what happens at L988 and the code in hookenv.relation_set. What am I missing?

If the problem is just the breaks, I am removing them in a new patchset.

I may be missing something but I don't understand the statement '...there is no is_leader() check, so all ncc units will have the data written to the relation' because with the 'break' there that is not what happens. Only the first unit will set the unit relation data.

'Maybe I'm failing to understand that corner case'. Let me rephrase it because its possible I'm  missing something in the logic of your patch:


Unit data is one to many, its from a single unit to all the units in the remote
application. So, imagine that the we have a new authorized key and only the first
nova-cloud-controller unit sets the key data on the relation (this is what would
happen with the 'break' inplace in your patch).

$ juju run --unit nova-cloud-controller/0 "relation-set -r cloud-compute:17 authorized_keys_42='newkey'"

This triggers a cloud-compute-relation-changed on all the nova-compute units but
the new data is only visible from the unit nova-cloud-controller/0.

$ juju run --unit nova-compute/0 "relation-get -r cloud-compute:17 authorized_keys_42 nova-cloud-controller/0"
newkey
$ juju run --unit nova-compute/0 "relation-get -r cloud-compute:17 authorized_keys_42 nova-cloud-controller/1"
$ juju run --unit nova-compute/0 "relation-get -r cloud-compute:17 authorized_keys_42 nova-cloud-controller/2"
$ juju run --unit nova-compute/0 "relation-get -r cloud-compute:17 authorized_keys_42 nova-cloud-controller/3"
$ 

Now simulate the lose of nova-cloud-controller/0

$ juju remove-unit --force nova-cloud-controller/0   
$ juju run --unit nova-compute/0 "relation-list -r cloud-compute:17"
nova-cloud-controller/1                                                                                                                  
nova-cloud-controller/2                                                                                                               
nova-cloud-controller/3
$ juju run --unit nova-compute/0 "relation-get -r cloud-compute:17 authorized_keys_42 nova-cloud-controller/1"
$ juju run --unit nova-compute/0 "relation-get -r cloud-compute:17 authorized_keys_42 nova-cloud-controller/2"
$ juju run --unit nova-compute/0 "relation-get -r cloud-compute:17 authorized_keys_42 nova-cloud-controller/3"

The newkey has gone because the unit that set the relation data has gone.

Application data is a one to one relation and is not dependent on a single unit.

$ juju run --unit nova-cloud-controller/2 "relation-set -r cloud-compute:17 authorized_keys_84='newkey' --app"
$ juju run --unit nova-compute/0 "relation-get -r cloud-compute:17 authorized_keys_84 nova-cloud-controller --app"
newkey

Now simulate the lose of the unit that set the data:

$ juju remove-unit --force nova-cloud-controller/2
$ juju run --unit nova-compute/0 "relation-list -r cloud-compute:17"
nova-cloud-controller/1
nova-cloud-controller/3

The application data is still available:

$ juju run --unit nova-compute/0 "relation-get -r cloud-compute:17 authorized_keys_84 nova-cloud-controller --app"
newkey
I'm fine without the break as the relation_sets will get aggregated and run at the end of hook. Thanks for reviewing this.

DEBUG and INFO logs cannot be duplicates. They have different goals and are applied in different cases and places.
DEBUG level is for developers in develop environment. DEBUG logs are not for production log parsing tools.
Operators basically work in production and log level on INFO level or above.
Debug log is placed in the start of function to notify that the work unit was started. Info log is placed in the end of function to notify that work unit was complete. It was already discussed many times in the review.

Hi Manoj, I know that because you've set to auto this isn't actually getting used, but if someone were to switch their configuration from auto to manual I would expect airship to continue to use calico. Can we change this to calico and use calico-ipam? We can talk about it tomorrow.

Hi.. The process is as below (from the multus docs) "Entrypoint script for for Multus CNI docker to overlay its configuration into locations in a filesystem. The configuration file will be copied to the corresponding configuration directory. When '--multus-conf-file=auto' is used, 00-multus.conf will be automatically generated from the CNI configuration file of the master plugin (the first file in lexicographical order in cni-conf-dir).  When '--multus-master-cni-file-name' is used, 00-multus.conf will be automatically generated from the specific file rather than the first file."

As described above, if you need to make it manual, the multus-master-conf should match the one with calico and set the --multus-conf-file with that name.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
given this has already merged i cant -1 it but i dont think this design is correct.
it will require external client to make 2 queries whenever this extention is present which will increase load on the neutron api and slow down any request that needs the security groups like a server show.

2 queries (1:tenant_id=xxx&shared=False 2:shared=True) are only needed when the client wants to get the security groups owned and shared for a given tenant. This patch does not change the behavior of calling v2.0/security-groups without any filters which still returns all the SGs that are accessible to the caller, including owned, shared, and other tenants'(if the caller is an admin).

neutron/extensions/security_groups_share.message:
i kind of think this is a design defect

we shoudl support getting all security group you can use in a singel query

so rahter then just the shared or not shared ones we should be able to say
return all security groups that are valide for me to see by passing shared=both or some other sential.
so this should be an enum filed not a boolean.

The patch follows the existing API behavior of other Neutron RBAC resources like networks, subnet_pools, etc. "return all security groups that are valid for me" can always and still be done by 1 API call to list without passing any filters (will return other projects' SGs if the caller is an admin). Instead of creating a new API to "return all SGs that are owned OR shared to a given tenant" (this kind of API behavior does not exist in Neutron), I chose to use the existing "shared" field and make it to be a filter in addition to the tenant_id.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Added more reviewers/potentially interested parties as Mark A is on vacation this week.

Hello all,

I looked at the kernel source and history a bit deeper, and I found the following:

In summary, the workqueue rescuer threads' affinities were correct for the 3.10 kernel (i.e., were using the CPUs listed in kthread_cpus= argument's value), but are not correct for the 5.10 kernel because of commit: 25834c73f93a ("sched: Fix a race between __kthread_bind() and sched_setaffinity()", included in v4.3), which makes the following change in the __alloc_workqueue_key function "kernel/workqueue.c":

```
                wq->rescuer = rescuer;
-               rescuer->task->flags |= PF_NO_SETAFFINITY;
+               kthread_bind_mask(rescuer->task, cpu_possible_mask);
                wake_up_process(rescuer->task);
```

Note that this part of the __alloc_workqueue_key function has since been refactored into a separate function named init_rescuer with commit 983c75153273 ("workqueue: separate out init_rescuer()", included in v4.16).

Due to the changes made by the first aforementioned commit, the workqueue rescuer threads no longer *inherit* their CPU affinities from the kthreadd thread, but the code instead sets their affinities to all possible CPUs. (Recall that kthreadd's CPU affinity is set to use kthread_cpus=.)

All this to say, this patch aligns the 5.10 kernel's behaviour to the 3.10 kernel's behaviour in terms of workqueue rescuer threads' affinities, and should not have a negative effect due to the fact that workqueue rescuer threads in the 3.10 kernel have always been affined to the platform CPUs/kthread_cpus.

I also have some test results that indicate that this patch correctly sets the CPU affinities of the workqueue rescuer threads.

Thank you.
Hello Jim,  Could you help to review it again?

I am fine with this change based on the fact we already have the 'kthread_cpus' existing in STX. The concept of 'kthread_cpus' will continue as technical debt as it has essentially been rejected upstream

https://lkml.org/lkml/2020/3/23/376

Even before reading Thomas and Frederic's comments I had the same feeling around exploiting the runtime manipulation of this and other behaviors.

At any rate +2 on this but we should contribute to and expect to move away from 'kthread_cpus' knowing it is going nowhere upstream.

kernel-std/centos/patches/0012-workqueue.message:
Hello Jim,

Good points.

In terms of definitions:

Housekeeping CPUs are any CPUs that are *not* specified with the isolcpus argument. isolcpus is usually set to a small subset of the available CPUs on the system, which leaves the rest for housekeeping tasks. However, kthread_cpus (which, in StarlingX terminology, sets the platform CPUs) is usually set to the first core on each CPU socket.

To clarify with an example: Assume that we have a 44 CPU core system. An example configuration is:

* kthread_cpus=0,1  -> platform CPUs
* isolcpus=8-11,30-33  -> isolated CPUs

isolcpus would set housekeeping CPUs to the complement set of isolated CPUs; that is, 0-7,12-29,34-43, which is a very large superset of kthread_cpus.

In terms of rationale for the changes:

* Unbound workqueues' CPU affinity is set by init scripts by writing to /sys/devices/virtual/workqueue/cpumask during boot-up. This patch sets the default to kthread_cpus instead of housekeeping CPUs for consistency. I realize that this is a "weak" reason, and hence perhaps this part of the patch could be dropped.

* Workqueue rescuer threads are affined to all possible CPUs without this patch, and this may impact users' tasks running on isolated CPUs. This issue was noticed by a colleague in the quality assurance team during the v5.10 kernel uprev and the debugging of cyclictest results -- I can forward the internal bug report link and the colleague's name to you in private.

Reading through this again, the above paragraph doesn't really say why.  "because the latter can be a superset of the former" just leaves me scratching my head.  There should be another sentence here starting with "We need to confine them to just the platform CPUs because....." And maybe a description of the difference between a platform cpu and a housekeeping cpu is in order.

  # create a server
  openstack server create --network private --flavor m1.medium --image cirros-0.5.2-x86_64-disk --wait test-server

  # ensure the network appears

  # create a port
  openstack port create --network private test-port

  # add the port to the server
  openstack server add port test-server test-port

  # ensure the port appears

This change extends the compute manager to append the cyborg
resource request to the libvirt driver when performing a
suspend and resume.

This change extends the ``suspend_instance`` and ``resume_instance``
rpcapi function to carry the ``accel_info``, which is the ARQs info
associated with the instance by quering Cyborg.

Main purpose of opendev AFS mirrors is to ensure locality in order to avoid network connectivity to create false CI failures, so we can minimize the content set to just what CI jobs needs.

> re. aarch64 - do we have CI jobs using that arch?

yes; not a lot, but both centos-8-arm64 and centos-8-stream-arm64 have active CI jobs.  i don't see why we won't want 9-stream

> Same for debug/source - I don't know there would be CI jobs that needed those?

I've certainly used them before when debugging issues.  The important thing is to have it available as easily as before with an --enablerepo -- currently we don't do anything related to this and just leave the separate debuginfo .repo file in the image alone.  with 9-stream it's all in one file, so we'll have to be careful in mirror setup steps to not refer to local mirrors if we drop this.

A self-consistent mirror seems like an improvement; I'd tend towards keeping these for that reason.  It's a space v. bespoke-ness (something that always gets us eventually) trade-off ... the numbers are there -- what do other admins think?

doc/source/admin/config-services-agent.r.message:
We don't, OVN has an AgentCache [1] that handles the OVN agents information in memory (OVN metatata and OVN controller/controller GW). This info is not stored in neutron.agents table.

When we try to update an OVN agent, there are no handlers for this request because we can't update anything. We can only delete an existing OVN agent. That will remove the AgentCache entry and the OVN SB chassis register. That feature was implemented for clean up purposes, in case an OVN controller was terminated not gracefully, leaving undeleted "chassis" registers in the OVS SB DB.

[1]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/899f254a091062d533beae303daabd6539954213/neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/agent/neutron_agent.py#L197

version in horizon https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/horizon/+/811412

> Patch Set 6:
> 
> we uncapped django, this should happen in this order imo.
> 
> 1. horizon updated to work with old and new versions of django (2.2/3.2 iirc)
> 1a. horizon as a lib is still used with plugins, running django 2
> 2. horizon released, supporting django 2 and 3
> 3. upper-constraints updated to use new horizon release
> 4. projects can set a minimum version of django 3 if they want (when using the horizon lib)
> 5. horizon plugins can use this release of horizon (as a lib) to migrate their support of django to version 3
> 6. horizon can drop support for django 2 and release a version (I'd say a major version bump) noting this in their requirements.txt
> 7. upper-constraints can be updated again for the new horizon release
> 8. projects that use horizon as a lib will be forced to use the new django at this point.

I was lazy enough when I post the last comment and did not write the full story.
I plan to write a page in the horizon contributor doc so that such confusion does not happen in future.

requirements-tox-py38-check-uc failure is valid. horizon is used as a library in horizon plugins, so horizon which accepts Django 3.2 needs to be released before updating upper-constraints.txt to Django 3.2. I believe this is the right step to bump the Django minimum version.
